titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Flora Stieglitz Straus Collection of Stieglitz Family Papers
Stieglitz Family Papers, Flora Stieglitz Straus Collection of
titlestmt.author: by Timothy Young and Sandra Markham

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 05:13
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

did.unittitle: Flora Stieglitz Straus collection of Stieglitz family papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Flora Stieglitz Straus Collection of Stieglitz Family Papers consists of letters, photographs, printed materials, journals, and a scrapbook documenting the lives of Alfred Stieglitz's extended family. Included in the first series, Stieglitz Family Papers, are letters between family members, a draft of an autobiography by Edward J. Stieglitz, and biographical information about Julius Stieglitz. Series II, Alfred Stieglitz and Georgia O'Keeffe, contains a number of letters from Stieglitz and Georgia O'Keeffe to Elizabeth Stieglitz Davidson and Donald Douglas Davidson, and to Flora Stieglitz Straus. Series III, Leopold Stieglitz, consists of material concerning his life, including several journals from the 1880s. Series IV, Addition (1999) contains a group of lantern slides that copy earlier family photographs. Series V, Addition (2000) adds several letters, photographs and family items. Series VI, Addition (2005) contains five autochromes made by Nathan Straus Jr., with their diascope viewers; portraits include Flora Stieglitz Straus, her husband Hugh Grant Straus, and her maternal grandmother Jacobina Staerk Stieffel. Series VII, Addition (2008) includes correspondence, financial papers, photographs, diaries, and albums that document the friends, travels, and activities of the Stieglitz family in Europe and New York City, as well as at their summer home, Oaklawn, just north of the village of Lake George, New York.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English with some letters and documents in German.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The majority of the items in this collection were the bequest of the estate of Flora Stieglitz Straus. Other items were given by Stieglitz family members Sue Davidson Lowe and Elizabeth Davidson Murray. Much of the material concerning Leopold Stieglitz was collected by Robert Simpson and given to Flora Stieglitz Straus by Mrs. Simpson in 1972. Material in Series V was given by Sue Davidson Lowe in 1999 and added to the collection in 2000. The autochromes in Series VI were given by Ann Straus Gertler. Material in Series VII is from the estate of Flora Stieglitz Straus.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Flora Stieglitz Straus Collection of Stieglitz Family Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Flora Stieglitz Straus Collection of Stieglitz Family Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 10: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Folders 181-184 (Cold storage): Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection originally consisted of three series and was processed in 1996. As family correspondence, photographs, and other material is subsequently acquired from Flora Stieglitz Straus's family members, it is appended to the collection, rather than incorporated; additions were made in 1999, 2000, 2005, and 2008.

p.ref: Alfred Stieglitz / Georgia O'Keeffe Archive (YCAL MSS 85)

bioghist.head: STIEGLITZ FAMILY
bioghist.p: Information about the Stieglitz family is readily available in many books about Alfred Stieglitz, including Sue Davidson Lowe's Stieglitz: A Memoir/Biography , which includes a detailed family tree that is very helpful in sorting out the photographer's extended family. The Flora Stieglitz Straus Collection contains a photocopy of a typescript draft of an autobiography by Edward J. Stieglitz ("Search for Maturity") that also includes biographical information about Julius Stieglitz. In addition, readers are directed to Herbert Newby McCoy's Julius Stieglitz, 1867-1937: A Biographical Sketch .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Flora Stieglitz Straus Collection of Stieglitz Family Papers consist of letters, photographs, printed materials, journals, manuscripts, albums, and a scrapbook documenting the lives of many members of Alfred Stieglitz's extended family, in particular his father Edward and brothers Julius and Leopold, with some early correspondence to and from Stieglitz. The collection spans the years 1860-1999 and was accumulated mainly by Flora Stieglitz Straus (1895-1994), the niece of Alfred Stieglitz. Material in this collection complements other family papers found in Series XI of the Alfred Stieglitz/Georgia O'Keeffe Archive (YCAL MSS 85).

Included in the first series, Stieglitz Family Papers, are letters between family members, a draft of an autobiography by Edward J. Stieglitz, and biographical information about Julius Stieglitz. Series II, Alfred Stieglitz and Georgia O'Keeffe, contains a number of letters from Stieglitz and O'Keeffe to Elizabeth Stieglitz Davidson and Donald Douglas Davidson, and to Flora Stieglitz Straus. Series III, Leopold Stieglitz, consists of material concerning him and includes several of his journals from the 1880s. Series IV, Addition (1999), is a collection of lantern slides. Series V, Addition (2000), contains several letters, photographs and family items. Series VI, Addition (2005), consists of five autochrome portraits and their viewing devices. Series VII, Addition (2008), includes correspondence, financial papers, photographs, and albums that document the travels and activities of the Stieglitz family in Europe, New York City, and at their summer home, Oaklawn, just north of the village of Lake George, New York.
Because the material in this collection came from a number of family sources, the same types of documents (correspondence, invoices, photographs, etc.) will appear in many of the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into seven series: I. Stieglitz Family (1867-1990); II. Alfred Stieglitz and Georgia O'Keeffe (1880-1992); III. Leopold Stieglitz (1878-1954); IV. Addition (1999): Lantern Slides (circa 1920); V. Addition (2000): Correspondence, Photographs, Other Papers (1863-1999); VI. Addition (2005): Autochromes (circa 1915); VII. Addition (2008): Manuscripts, Photographs, Ephemera (1860-1945). Boxes 8, 9, and 18 contain Oversize items. Box 10 contains Restricted Fragile Papers for which preservation copies have been made.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Correspondence; Photographs; and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds a variety of letters, photographs, and family papers. Correspondence contains letters between family members, which include several picture postcards collected by Sue Davidson Lowe. Photographs contains many portraits of family members, including the twin brothers Leopold and Julius Stieglitz, and images of Stieglitz family homes in Lake George and Mamaroneck, New York. [Copy negatives for several prints accompanied this collection. They are stored separately.] Among the Other Papers is the draft of an autobiography by gerontologist Edward J. Stieglitz ("Search for Maturity," which also contains biographical information about his father Julius Stieglitz), and a scrapbook kept by Elizabeth Stieffel Stieglitz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series brings together materials documenting the life of the photographer and his second wife that were collected by several family members. Along with the clippings and exhibition catalogs are a number of runs of correspondence. These include letters from Alfred Stieglitz to Elizabeth Stieglitz Davidson and Donald Douglas Davidson, and to Elizabeth Stieffel Stieglitz, Leopold Stieglitz, and Flora Stieglitz Straus, as well as letters from Georgia O'Keeffe to Donald Douglas Davidson, to Elizabeth Stieglitz Davidson, and to Flora Stieglitz Straus. This series also contains a typescript carbon of an essay ("Joke") by Benjamin de Casseres written for "291" and a bookplate for Alfred Stieglitz most likely designed by Allen Lewis.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: Correspondence; Clippings; Exhibition Catalogs; Printed Items; and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains papers related to Alfred Stieglitz's younger brother Leopold, who gained renown as a physician. The first subseries contains routine personal and professional Correspondence . The second subseries, Writings , consists of items on medical topics along with stories and plays. Among the Personal Papers are several volumes of journals that cover Stieglitz's school days in Germany during the 1880s, and his diplomas and awards.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Correspondence; Writings; and Personal Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains a group of lantern slides that copy earlier family photographs. Descriptions of the images were taken from a list provided by Sue Davidson Lowe; according to a note accompanying the material, Flora Straus recalled in 1986 that the slides were probably made for her by Alfred Stieglitz, and were shown at a family New Years Eve celebration in the early 1920s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: By Leopold Stieglitz; By Leopold or Julius Stieglitz; and Studio Photographs, Groups and Portraits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains five autochromes and their diascope viewers. Three photographs are of Flora Stieglitz Straus, with one each of her husband Hugh Grant Straus (1890-1961), and her maternal grandmother Jacobina Staerk Stieffel; they were made around 1915 by Nathan Straus Jr. (1889-1961), the brother of Hugh Straus. The diascopes are leather-covered transparency viewing devices patented in 1908 by the New York manufacturer L. A. Dubernet; each holder has a mirror on the back of a folding bellows which allows light to reflect back through the autochrome.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Color reference prints of the five portraits are filed in the front of box 14.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains a variety of letters and personal papers, photographs, and friendship albums. The first subseries, Manuscripts , includes a series of letters written by Alfred Stieglitz while a he was student in Germany, other letters written to Edward Stieglitz by family and friends, a set of hotel receipts documenting the Stieglitz family's travels in Germany and Switzerland in 1866, and invoices for household expenditures in Lake George and furnishings for their home in New York. It also holds friendship volumes kept by two of the Stieglitz sisters, Agnes and Selma, which were inscribed and drawn in by their friends and family members in Europe and America, including the artists Fedor Encke, Moses Jacob Ezekiel, Wilhelm Hasemann, and Otto Rauth. Also present are two partial diaries kept by Edward Stieglitz and his granddaughter Katherine ("Kitty") Stieglitz Stearns.

Photographs is arranged under the headings of Albums, Individuals, Groups, and Miscellaneous. There are three photograph albums which hold snapshot-quality images of the Stieglitz family at home and at play in Europe and New York City (Manhattan and Queens), and at Lake George. Many of the images in box 17 are duplicated in other series in this collection, as well as in the Stieglitz/O'Keeffe Archive (YCAL MSS 85). Ephemera holds theatre handbills from performances in Germany in 1866.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Manuscripts; Photographs; and Ephemera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains sentimental prose and poetry, and with drawings and watercolors by Fedor Encke, Wilhelm Hasemann, Otto Rauth, and Edward Stieglitz; signers are friends and family in Weimar, Berlin, Mittenwald, Vienna, New York City, and Lake George, NY; includes silhouette portrait of Alfred Stieglitz dated January 27, 1885.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Purchased in Munich, cover gold-stamped "Sellie;" contains sentimental prose and poetry, drawings and watercolors, one photograph (by Alfred Stieglitz) and one etching; inscribed by friends and family in Munich, Rome, New York City, and Lake George, NY, and include Fedor Encke, Moses Ezekiel, and Alfred Stieglitz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small cropped snapshots of family members at Oaklawn, Saratoga, New York City, Prospect Mountain, and Far Rockaway (Queens, NY); many beach bathing, boating, golfing, and bicycling scenes; many photos of dogs, including Drew.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of family members; buildings and people in Germany; scenes at Oaklawn; some interiors (perhaps in New York City); many are portraits of Stieglitz family children; possible portrait of the artist Wilhelm Hasemann; many taken by Alfred Stieglitz and Edward Steichen.
